dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the mirror the DRIVER watches TWO YOUNG TROOPERS getti out of their car behind. He reaches out to his right, unobtrusively unlatches the passenger-side door. Then he gets a PISTOL from the glove compartment and slips it out of sight under road map open on the seat beside him. Sitting cool and eaSy, he watches the lst Trooper stop back of his right rear fender. He pats his pockets, makes a sheepish show of searching for a wallet as the 2nd Troo comes on up to open window.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Wouldn't you know? I don't have it on me. : so 2nd TROOPER’ Step out, please.

dialogues.speaker: , DRIVER
dialogues.text: Out of the car? What for? 2nd TROOPER dust get out. Not too fast. Driver about to protest, but then he sees Trooper's hand down to holster. Driver pops his eyes in kind of scared surprise, obediently fumbles at the door handle. That's h last fumble. : Like a steel spring he throws himself back flat on the se and with both feet kicks driver's-side door Savagely open into gut of Trooper standing at it, and keeps on rolling right out through unlatched door on other side, and lands in a crouch with that gun in his hand and FIRES point-bla at Trooper back of fender, and spins around in front and_ FIRES AGAIN at 2nd Trooper writhing windless on blacktop where door slammed him. . :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh sweet hell. . "PAST PULL BACK as he turns. ‘Now we see a STATE POLICE B parked just beyond where sedan stopped. There are a DOZEN ROOKIE TROOPERS standing in the road, watching in some aw The driver, who is LIEUTENANT FRADY, lowers his blank- cartridge pistol fairly disgustedly.

dialogues.speaker: . FRADY
dialogues.text: Each of you. Write me five reasons that would never happen to you. That's all. Prady shakes his head again at the Trooper still down on the blacktop, steps over him and gets back into car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prady slams the doors and starts the engine and turns on his radio. He picks up its microphone, blows in it.

dialogues.speaker: . . PRADY
dialogues.text: One=niner to Central. Leaving training area. Anything up?

dialogues.speaker: . 1 . RADIO VOICE
dialogues.text: Hello, One-niner. Victim in that wreck last night on I-Seven been identified. Tucker, Michael.

dialogues.speaker: FRADY -
dialogues.text: Rings no bell. Should it?

dialogues.speaker: RADIO VOICE
dialogues.text: Morgue just called. They found a Slip in the guy's pocket -- with your name and address on it. Frady' s surprised for an instant, but it's hard to tell. He never shows much expression.

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: I'll look at him. One-niner out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANDREW WINSTON gets out of an elevator. Well-dressed man youngish 50s. It won't surprise us when we learn he's a» college professor. Winston is crossing to go out front do when he meets Frady coming in. They both stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant. : ,

dialogues.speaker: FPRADY
dialogues.text: Answer's still No.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Please. Listen to me. I don't excuse what he did, but he's one of the best students I've ever. had. Really exceptional.

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: That I'll buy. ' Point one~five - drunk and stoned -- and tries to slug a trooper with a bottle.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: I'd call the last score settled, Lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: I just saw him, and I wonder -- would your men have beaten him quite so badly if he wasn't black?

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: Charges of brutality must be put in writing. . cone,

dialogues.speaker: . WINSTON
dialogues.text: Just wondering.

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: Walk along with me a minute. Prady heads for a door beside elevators. Winston falls in with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They emerge from a stairwell. As Frady starts to lead around a corner, Winston stops. CAMERA PANS to a sign on the wall. It says "MORGUE" with a pointing arrow.

dialogues.speaker: . WINSTON
dialogues.text: What's the idea?

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: Wilcox is upstairs in the prison ward with a busted head. I'm showing you where he ought to be. (as Winston just . stands there) He was in a stolen car. He made a move at an officer. He's very "lucky and the charges don't get aropped.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: But he has -- he had -- such a really great future.

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: Lots of us had.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Not that I like this tack -- do you know who I am? A beat. PFrady's tone goes even flatter.

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: Andrew Winston. Professor.of American History up at State U.

dialogues.speaker: . WINSTON
dialogues.text: Before that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I know the position you had. Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ad 1% .

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: I had some influence, Lieutenant. in fairly high places. I might be able to turn it on again.

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: Do me the favor of my life. Try that. Frady's eyes bore into him. Winston turns and exits up th Stairway. Frady continues on his way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ATTENDANT sits at a desk outside double swinging doors He has a cold cigar butt in his mouth and is mentally jac off over an open Playboy mag. Frady comes up behind him.

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: You'll grow hair inside your skull. (as fellow looks up) Visitor for Tucker, Michael.’

dialogues.speaker: ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Let's hope he's in. Attendant gets up. MOVE with him and Frady through the swinging doors. Chilly air in the morgue-proper hits Frady and makes Him immediately sneeze.

dialogues.speaker: . FRADY
dialogues.text: Pardon.

dialogues.speaker: ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: No sweat. Nothin' bothers the guests in this hotel. Let's see now -- Mr. Tucker's suite -- : They've reached wall of big pull-out drawers. CAMERA DROP with Attendant as he locates one in bottom tier. Typed ca in slot says: "TUCKER, M."

dialogues.speaker: . . ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: We're in luck. Ain't got his Do Not Disturb sign out. CAMERA TILTS UP as guy rolls out the drawer. Frady squint down, not enjoying the o-s. view one bit.

dialogues.speaker: ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Face familiar? CONT.

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: Not a bit. te ATTENDANT It's a shame.

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: I mean all I get is guys who've done head-on's at a hundred into bridges. Never nothin’ like out of Playboy. .

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: Boy. I'd sure hate my sister to wind up around here. . Frady pivots quickly and EXITS SHOT.

EXT. STATE POLICE HQ - DAY” ESTABLISH a good modern building in open countryside. ‘Terrain is fairly flat, with a haze of high mountains in _ extreme distance. It could be eastern Colorado. Frady parks his sedan in an official slot in front and goes into the building. - . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Frady walks along, a young UNIFORMED TROOPER passes him in opposite direction, carrying some papers. He makes funny knowing eyes at Frady and lets out a low WHISTLE. Frady stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corporal Harmon. a 7 CPL. HARMON Sir? :

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: Why you whistle at me, Harmon?

dialogues.speaker: CPL. HARMON
dialogues.text: I was just whistling, sir. That's not persuasive, but Frady loses interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Harmon. Get going. 'Fore | I run you in for mopery with ‘ “intent to gawk.  7.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Harmon unstiffens and gets going quick. Frady turns a corner. We can read lettering on the closed door at end ahead of him: "CRIMINAL INVESTIGATION DIVISION. LT, FRADY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frady enters and stops short, like seeing a ghost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GIRL is standing by the window. Her name is HILDY. She' in her early 30s and quite attractive enough to explain C Harmon's whistle, and her attempt to hide her obvious unc tainty isn't very good.

dialogues.speaker: RILDY
dialogues.text: Hello, Frady. Surprise.

dialogues.speaker: CU
dialogues.text: He just looks at her.- His eyes are strangely cold. Then his eyes go off her as ANGLE LOOSENS. Making a point of not looking at her, he hangs his jacket on a hook but . heaves on his shoulder holster as he goes to desk and y open a bottom drawer.

dialogues.speaker: . FPRADY
dialogues.text: How you get in here?

dialogues.speaker: HILDY
dialogues.text: Said I was engaged to you. No look, no comment. Frady takes a bottle from the drawer Antique label says “Sloane's Horse Liniment," but it's probably not that because he uncaps it and drinks a slug. . ’ HILDY I had a heck of a time finding you. I never dreamed you'd be a policeman.

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: Me neither.

dialogues.speaker: HILDY
dialogues.text: I'm terribly glad you are..

dialogues.speaker: . FRADY
dialogues.text: I‘tm glad you're glad. Why?

dialogues.speaker: . HILDY
dialogues.text: It's the damndest thing. It's -- Look at me, won't you? CONT.  oy ‘ oO

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He won't. He sticks bottle away, wipes mouth with back of hand, starts shuffling papers on his desk.

dialogues.speaker: PRADY
dialogues.text: Talk of damnedest things. Your first name's Hildy, but in -- ‘let's see -- ummm -- in nine years, I've forgot your last.

dialogues.speaker: HILDY -
dialogues.text: Miller. Look at me.

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: Hildy Miller -- don't you know why seeing you makes me so sad? ™

dialogues.speaker: HILDY
dialogues.text: Of course. I don't like to be reminded either. : FPRADY . Then what's the score?

dialogues.speaker: HILDY
dialogues.text: Someone wants to kill us, Prady.

dialogues.speaker: CU
dialogues.text: He turns his head at last. He looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: Us. WIDEN to include Hildy. She looks at him fixedly, neds in the most serious way you ever saw.

dialogues.speaker: . PRADY
dialogues.text: Wants to kill you and me. (gets another nod) The both of us. Murder us. (and another) Who?

dialogues.speaker: HILDY
dialogues.text: I don't know. Silence. Frady's lips are suddenly ary. He wets them and looks down again, continues shuffling papers. Hildy comes and leans toward him with her palms flat on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ay

dialogues.speaker: HILDY
dialogues.text: You should ask why.

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: That'd be dumb.

dialogues.speaker: HILDY
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: We were together just one night and one morning. It couldn't be the night, so it's gotta be <= (after a beat, low and halting) . 11:12 ayem. Where we were. What we saw. The -=- uh -=- Jesus, and I swore I'd never think of : it again’=- the -- uh -- damn, I don't like to say it even -- the assassination. ,

dialogues.speaker: HILDY
dialogues.text: Yes. : It has been said and answered. The word hangs there like little hissing snake. More silence. Frady still looks dow shuffles papers. : .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on. Ask questions. -

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: Ummmn. You still flying with. the airline?

dialogues.speaker: HILDY-
dialogues.text: Yes. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Been in any crashes? Had any mental treatments? Hildy's mouth opens. Frady jabs button in his INTERCOM BO speaks quickly into it:

dialogues.speaker: , _ PRADY
dialogues.text: Prady here. Lady in my office can't find her way out. Send - Harmon in to help her. CONT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ay © ra) ey 9A. CONTINUED : , ‘

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look -- I'm not kidding -- I can show you evidence, I can --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You look. Guys who pick up airline girls for romantic weekends deserve any trouble they get, but this one's too sick for me. Go find a good shrink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You damn male chauvinist! Wait till you hear from Mike Tucker! CU - FRADY a ~ He blinks just once. The prices have changed a little.

dialogues.speaker: PEATURE HILDY
dialogues.text: Beside herself with indignation, she grabs her purse and heads for door. She's in the hall before Frady catches up behind. If.you didn't know better, you might think from his tone that he was only mildly interested. CONT.

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: Who's Mike Tucker?

dialogues.speaker: HILDY
dialogues.text: He's a man! You might believe hin! we

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: You figure he'll contact me.

dialogues.speaker: HILDY
dialogues.text: Probably not, Lieutenant. He's on their list too. I bet they'll murder him while you're still standing with your thumb up it!

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: Where you staying?

dialogues.speaker: HILDY
dialogues.text: Motel. The “OK Corral." What's it to you? : Had a bum day. Sorry how I been. Stay in and I'll stop by after - supper and look at your evidence. HILDY . You're humoring me, Frady. You . . ~ won't stop by. .

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: Policeman's honor.

dialogues.speaker: .HILDY
dialogues.text: (still burning) Dumb crack about guys who pick up airline hostesses -- man, you can put that triple in reverse! Cpl. Harmon is coming down the hall. Hildy doesn't wait for him. She zooms past him and Harmon looks at Frady questioningly. Frady shuts the door in his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remains of dead cars are piled all over., We find one wre on a hoist a couple’ of féet above the ground, its four wheels removed. It looks the way a car should look after it has gone head-on at speed into a concrete abutment. CONT.  oy il.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Frady prowls around it, examining it closely. He's studyi the bulged-out smashed windshield when a YARD MAN comes u

dialogues.speaker: YARD MAN
dialogues.text: We got the rubber off the rims. What's left of ‘em. Frady walks across a little way with the Yard Man. The fo wheel rims lie on the ground, stripped of tires. Frady squats down by the pair of them which are knocked egg-sha

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: These are the fronts, huh? YARD MAN . Yuh. What you lookin' to find : exackly? ~™

dialogues.speaker: PRADY
dialogues.text: Dunno exackly. . (as guy watches) Thanks. You can get back to work. Yard Man gets the idea. He walks away. Prady turns the wheels on the ground, studying the hollow inside of rims where the tires used to be set. He pauses suddenly, with narrowed eyes. :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a regular little indentation in one of them. A small punched-in holiow in the steel, like could have bee made by a rifle bullet. fFrady sticks a forefinger in it. PAN to the other wheel rim. It lies with its bent oval shape matching the first, but there is no iittle hollowed indentation in this one. ANGLE - FRADY .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up. What he's discovered is thought-provoking. CAMERA PULLS BACK to a WIDE ANGLE. We see Frady deep in those thoughts, walking up and down in front of terrible heaped wasteland of junk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The junkyard has slewly become this gleaming edifice. It stands in the sunlight as a TROOP OF SCHOOLCHILDREN mount the steps, debouching with their guides from buses parked below. The kids are suitably solemn and awed by it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a big one. A session is in progress: some sort o House Appropriations Sub-Committee affair. There's a scat tering of PEOPLE in the seats, watching and listening. EDWARD TRUMBULL sits in the witness seat. He's a very wel tailored type in his 40s: they didn't break the mold afte they made Dean Acheson, evidently. Facing him over the bi paper-strewn table are SEVERAL CONGRESSMEN. The CHAIRMAN is a small Southerner, string-tied and rimless-glassed. T . pencils in front of him are very sharp, and we know fro i eyes that he is a fierce guardian of the public purse.

dialogues.speaker: CHAIRMAN
dialogues.text: Correct me if I am in error, suh. Your name is Edward Trumbull. You are the Director of the Bureau of Social Structure.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMBULL
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CHAIRMAN
dialogues.text: I presume you know the purpose of this hearing, Mr. Trumbull?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toe Yes, sir. To examine my bureau's - request for funding in the coming fiscal year. a Congressmen look at papers in front of them. Fellow nex : to Chairman makes a face and whispers something. Chairm nods, addresses himself again to the witness.

dialogues.speaker: . CHAIRMAN
dialogues.text: . Some of us aren't quite clear as - to the function of your department, . Mr. Trumbull. Could you help us?

dialogues.speaker: TRUMBULL
dialogues.text: With pleasure, sir. The Bureau of Social Structure was organized in 1958, during the Eisenhower administration, under PL 10451 dash 2. It is charged with -- I quote -- the continuing study of social structures as developed within the United States as made- by its.citizens in response to conduct of the Federal Government. \i -A beat of awkward silence. One Committee Member bites peevishly on his cigar. CONT.

dialogues.speaker: THAT MEMBER
dialogues.text: Worst gobbledygook I ever heard. What's that mean in English?

dialogues.speaker: TRUMBULL
dialogues.text: (charmingly) . I sympathize, sir. The language of that era often was obscure. Let me explain it ‘another way --

dialogues.speaker: CHAIRMAN
dialogues.text: . (banging gavel) No, suh. You will not.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMBULL
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon? CHAIRMAN _ o™ Gentlemen, allow me to draw some amazin' facts to your attention. It's on that sheet you all have, (as they look) , In each and every year since it was started, this Bureau has requested somewhat less money than it received the year before. Not only that, it has moved on four occasions into smaller quarters and operated with fewer : . personnel. I find this record usnique and without precedent in my experience. Speaking for myself, therefore, I don't give a dang what this whatchamacallit Bureau does -- just wish there was more like it. All in favor?

dialogues.speaker: THE COMMITTEE
dialogues.text: Aye! .. :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Trumbull suh, your Bureau's request for funding is approved as made. (bangs gavel again) Step over here, please, and we'll all shake your hand -- Trumbull rises with‘a debonair smile, leans across and starts shaking hands. The people in the seats applaud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congressmen magically become figures on a cute ANIMATED N SIGN. They walk each other down along multicolor tubing a draw guns and little neon bullets zap out and everyone fa dead. They start it again as CAMERA PULLS BACK. Old- fashioned light bulbs spell out name over the endless neo Slaughter: "OK CORRAL MOTEL." We see Frady entering the lobby. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frady leans on counter as CLERK checks registration file. Frady is in usual civvies, of course, but he is well know in these parts. :

dialogues.speaker: . CLERK
dialogues.text: 114. Nothing wrong, is there? -

dialogues.speaker: PRADY .
dialogues.text: Not I know of. Do you? WITH FRADY . Getting quick headshake, he heads away toward exit to roo area. The super-cornball lobby depresses him. Clerk and _ rest of staff affect phony cowboy gear. Frady pauses a moment by souvenir stand, watching a YOUNG MAN buying a dreadful little lamp made of cactus with a plastic cowboy hat shade. His eyes ask how could anyone want such a thin The Young Man sees Frady and winks at him.

dialogues.speaker: . YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Light to make love by. Bang bang. Frady hurries on. He hears PIANO MUSIC. It comes from entrance to bar. Sign over archway naturally says: “Black Bart's Saloon.“ fFrady angles over and looks in. There's a surprisingly nice GIRL playing piano, just finishing a song. Frady eyes his watch.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BAR
dialogues.text: Frady enters the dim-lit place, goes up to the fairly crowded mahogany counter.

dialogues.speaker: . BARTENDER.
dialogues.text: What's yer poison, pard? Spot o' redeye?

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: (not amused)” Jack D.. Water on the side. CONT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: _ is. CONTINUED : . He peels off a buck and goes to the piano. Despite her co greeting, the Girl's eyes are glad to see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some nerve, ol' .pig.

dialogues.speaker: . FRADY
dialogues.text: Yuh, I know, I should've called, Claire -- I been busy -- out of town on something -- (enough lies) What you doin' later?

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Supporting my local police? Frady nods, pleased. He goes back toward bar. . ~

dialogues.speaker: FULL SCREEN
dialogues.text: It packs a big wallop. It's a grainy enlargement of a POL ASSASSINATION. It's no particular event that we can ident in time or place but it has elements of all of them. The is turned away so we cannot see his face, but a piece of skull is obscurely detached and seems to be taking wing. A FLASH of that, and a small o.s. CLICK SOUND, and we get ANOTHER SLIDE. Same event from a different angle, seen pe three seconds later. The victim is falling now, though we still NEVER SEE HIS FACE, and there is a fine spray that be blood, and the PEOPLE AROUND are now perceiving. Mouth opened in existential terror as in Munch's painting of a Just a PLASH of that one too, and the o.s. CLICK and we g third slide. This one will remain a while. It shows same unspeakable event from yet another angle. A group of SPEC watching from some distance. Setting might be a PUBLIC PA The feature of it is this: perhaps TWENTY SPECTATORS in t frozen shot, all but three of whom have had their faces C IN BLACK INK on the negative with VARIOUS DATES INKED ALO Dates like 12/9/64 and 4/19/65 and so on. The THREE PEOPL extreme right hand edge of slide are NOT CIRCLED AND DATE These are ONE MAN by himself, and a BLURRY COUPLE who see have been holding hands as the photographer caught them. NO SOUND for a bit, just o.s. BREATHING, and then: : - . ’ CONT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: " 1Sa.

dialogues.speaker: HILDY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I guess you saw this when it came out in the magazine. Who didn't?

dialogues.speaker: PRADY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Hildy walks up INTO SHOT in front of PROJECTION and indic the BLURRY UNCIRCLED COUPLE at right edge.

dialogues.speaker: HILDY
dialogues.text: You realize this is us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Showing this curious photo being projected on a wall from little home-slide gizmo. The room is pretty well dark, wae CONT.  16.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: pS drapes over patio doors pulled shut. Frady walks up an inspects the photo closer. His voice is totally neutral. Could tell it was 25 you, maybe « But the guy's too urred, wouldn't know him. Don't think anyone would.

dialogues.speaker: HILDY
dialogues.text: Frady.

dialogues.speaker: PRADY
dialogues.text: . Okay. It's us. .

dialogues.speaker: HILDY
dialogues.text: Tucker sent me this a couple of weeks ago. He's a magazine writer. He was planning one of those Where Are They Now things. So he did some research and he found -- _ What do you think the dates are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - . - . I don't want to think. 7 . (as she just waits and looks at him) Obituaries?

dialogues.speaker: HILDY
dialogues.text: oO On the nose.

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: . All of them? oF HILDY ’ . Right again, Frady.

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: Impossible. How? € : HILDY Accidents. FRADY ’ (broken record) . All of them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every one. Maine to California. Tucker dug in and found every one was listed a closed-case accident. Here's a copy of his notes. CONT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ay 17. CONTINUED . Hildy picks up a sheaf of typewritten xerox copies from bureau top. She hands them to him. He takes them like they were red hot. He frowns, reads the heading of top sheet aloud:

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: “Arthur Faversham. Drowned while fishing. Salmontail River, Idaho."

dialogues.speaker: HILDY
dialogues.text: That was the last one. Now there's just Tucker and us. How's it feel?

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: What feel?

dialogues.speaker: HILDY
dialogues.text: Being on the wrong side of the fence. Having someone after you.

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: He doesn't reply, stares at the sheet. Hildy comes over to him. yo, HILDY - Go to Idaho. It wasn't so long ago. See what you can find.

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: . Another state. Not my turf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go anyway. What's to lose? It beats being a sitting duck. . FPrady rubs back of his neck. He tosses notes down on bed and flicks off the slide projector and crosses to turn up air conditioner. | PRADY . Making me hot. Dumb coincidences always make me hot.

dialogues.speaker: HILDY
dialogues.text: Coincidence, huh?

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: Oh coma on. You know it. ° '  18.

dialogues.speaker: HILDY
dialogues.text: _ She marches over and turns the projector on again as Fr turns in b.g. : BILDY . Look again. The dates, Left to right.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE PROJECTION
dialogues.text: CAMERA JUMPS from circle-date to circle-date, stitching t left to right. HOLDS suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: . FRADY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Sonofabitch. They're in order! CAMERA JUMPS BACK and retraces pattern. We see now if we~ didn't before: the dates are indeed in exact calendar ord

dialogues.speaker: HILDY ,
dialogues.text: Right again, Frady. Seventeen people die in perfect order from left to right -- one after the other, not one. out of order. You call that coincidence? Frady can find nothing to say. Stares from projection to Hildy and back again, sits on edge of bed. As Hildy turns on room lights and kills projector herself, PHONE RINGS. She picks it up quickly. - -

dialogues.speaker: HILDY
dialogues.text: Yes? -- I see. Thank you. (hanging up) Tucker was going to meet me here today. Hasn't showed up, and he's not where he lives either.

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: Sonofabitch. HILDY . You said that before. Now say it doesn't make sense,

dialogues.speaker: . ' FPRADY
dialogues.text: Shit. We were just out for air. We didn't even know the guy was coming through. Those conspiracy theories are crocks of shit. But i ‘even if there was one, how could you and me be invelyed?

dialogues.speaker: HILDY
dialogues.text: We were on that damn grassy knoll. Someone thinks we saw something.

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: But we didn't.

dialogues.speaker: HILDY
dialogues.text: Of course -- but they don’t know. So they're killing everyone, just to be sure. That's what Tucker and I decided. Beat that idea with a better one.

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: fry Tucker as a psycho. . :

dialogues.speaker: RILDY NO
dialogues.text: He isn't. ,

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: Try him. He's got this old slide ‘ and some ink and a case-of galloping _ paranoia. The rest is in his head,

dialogues.speaker: HILDY
dialogues.text: You've got his notes. You're the detective -- check them out. ° FRADY Sounds more like a job for the FBI.

dialogues.speaker: HILDY
dialogues.text: You darn fool -- Tucker went to them already. © (bitterly) And guess what.

dialogues.speaker: PRADY
dialogues.text: They wanted to fit hin a strait~ jacket.

dialogues.speaker: HILDY . .-
dialogues.text: Exactly! .

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: Okay. I'm taking the slide and. these notes. I'll get back to you after E look 'em over.’ : He picks the stuff up and heads for ‘the door, fairly abr . ” CONT.  20.

dialogues.speaker: HILDY
dialogues.text: Frady -- . (when he turns) I'm seared. They could be.on my trail. Lo PRADY -Assuming there is a “they.”

dialogues.speaker: HILDY
dialogues.text: Of course there is. And you should be scared too. Because if they're after me, now I've led them to you.

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: I doubt it.

dialogues.speaker: HILDY
dialogues.text: How can you say that?

dialogues.speaker: PRADY
dialogues.text: You went to the police. No one could guess you went to a policeman. I'm a tree hid in the forest. She comes closer to him, her eyes begging. :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm still scared, Frady. Please. — I -- I don’t feel much like being alone.

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: Take a nice hot bath and chain the door. Not to worry. I'll call you. He's gone before she can Say 2 thing more. Alone, she doe look scared. She slips the door chain in its slot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frady sits alone under a lamp. He wears shorts only, sips a drink as he broods over xeroxed notes he took from Hild Low from RADIO comes a farm and commodity report. It give the time as something after 3 a.m. Frady puts the notes down suddenly, eyes a telephone. . He changes his mind. CAMERA WITH HIM as he crosses and lo into bedroom. We glimpse Claire sprawled under sheet, sle ing contentedly. Her dress. and things are scattered on t floor. Stealthy, Frady goes in to get his own clothes, wh are laid out neat on a chair.  21.

dialogues.speaker: CU
dialogues.text: It shimmers, and we realize it is UNDERWATER. The CAMERA- PULLS UP a bit. Now we see that radio lies on bottom of _ a bathtub, with its cord plugged into an outlet beside washstand. Hildy Miller lies in the tub too, face down, her hair floating on the surface like a funeral wreath. Some small SOUND o.s. and ANGLE SHIFTS again. Frady appea in bathroom doorway . NIGHT CLERK is behind him, with a p key. The guy's pasty face comes unglued.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT CLERK
dialogues.text: Holy mother.

dialogues.speaker: INT, STATE POLICE HQ
dialogues.text: This one belongs to CAPT. RINTELS. He reads a report as Frady sits studying the rug. : :

dialogues.speaker: RINTELS
dialogues.text: You knew her. She's passing through and calls you. Why you look so guilty?

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: Well, I -- I walked out on her about 9 p.m. If I'd stayed, it wouldn't of happened.

dialogues.speaker: RINTELS
dialogues.text: Sure. And if the moon was made . ’ of green cheese. 7 (scans report again) It was an accident. Everybody's been questioned. You not hiding any facts, are you? A beat. Frady shakes his head and stands up.

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: Nothing definite. (starting out) Forget it, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: RINTELS
dialogues.text: Not so fast. Sgt. Dreben tells me you said to hang a wiretap on Carlton after the court denied an order. ’

dialogues.speaker: PRADY
dialogues.text: The bastard deals H. You know it and I know it. Ask me, the judge is getting his cut. . . CONT.  m a 22.

dialogues.speaker: RINTELS .
dialogues.text: My God, Lieutenant. I think you must be cracking up. Another beat. Frady's expression changes.

dialogues.speaker: . . FRADY
dialogues.text: Yuh. I do feel kind of bushed. How 'bout a few days leave to go fishing?

dialogues.speaker: RINTELS
dialogues.text: (instantly) Request granted. Get lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The river runs through dark sweet. pines, joined here by smaller stream. The waters have carved a shelf into rocky outrap, and under it is a wide black pool. CAMERA finds Frady, in old clothes, lying at the end of that shelf and gazing down. Swirl of water, a fish rising and as it jumps from the surface suddenly the SCREEN FLAR ALMOST WHITE and over the residual image these words appe “NATURE IS THE PROPER TEACHER OF

dialogues.speaker: IN AUTHORITY, COURAGE
dialogues.text: -- cee --The Handbook, Bureau Of Social Structure." Words FADE OUT as key returns to normal. The fish is vanished. Frady works himself back from the ledge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prady, in jacket and waders, stands at open trunk of car parked on shoulder, setting up his fly rod. It is not the police sedan he drove before. Frady looks down at a map lying open in the trunk. We see it over his shoulder. Highly detailed local job, with legend printed at top: “IDAHO. NORTH FORK SALMONTAIL. SHEET 4." We may recog- nize the confluence of river and side stream just seen. Below it, an arrow has been marked in ink. Frady shuts the trunk lid, walks toward the river with rod and creel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He works his way expertly downstream along a gravelly bar Shadows grow longer: it becomes SUNSET. Frady is touching CONT.  ot oO Qo 23.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: up his dry fly, smoothing wings, when he seems to sense something. He turns his head slowly. PAN to stand of pine behind him. MOVE IN CLOSER on it. Motionless figure of a MAN there, watching from just inside the trees. The setting sun at his back renders the figure an anonymous silhouette. .

dialogues.speaker: PRADY
dialogues.text: Howdy! You lookin' to see my license?

dialogues.speaker: INTO PINES
dialogues.text: No answer. Figure is so still we begin to doubt it, but. then it moves and melts away into the trees. ~

dialogues.speaker: -FRADY
dialogues.text: Continues peering a bit, then turns back to river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rundown old place. Weatherbeaten cabins beside a frame - house that serves as office too. Sign welcomes hunters and fishermen, but no sign of anyone staying here, just the owner's pickup parked by the house. Frady drives in and gets out of car, still wearing his fishing jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just a desk area in front hall. Frady finishes fill- ing out registration card as motel owner watches him. He is HENRY PELIKAS. Seems a friendly soul, glad to have someone to chat with in this obviously failing place. Prady hands him registration card.

dialogues.speaker: PELIKAS
dialogues.text: {eyeing it) John Harmon. Once knew a fella named Harmon. i

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: That's interesting. Anywhere nearby to eat? . . . > . ‘ CONT.  oO y 24.

dialogues.speaker: PELIKAS -
dialogues.text: Greasy spoon about half a mile. Or I could give you a bowl of lamb stew here if you wanta take a chance. Wouldn't mind havin' company, to be frank.

dialogues.speaker: . FRADY
dialogues.text: Thanks. Me neither. It's seven bucks, right?

dialogues.speaker: PELIKAS
dialogues.text: Right. Pick a key. Frady peels off money, turns to board where keys hang.

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: (picking it) . ~ Lucky seven. :

dialogues.speaker: PELIKAS
dialogues.text: Well, maybe. Or maybe not so. (as Frady looks a , question) . . . Nothin'. Skip it. I guess you - want to wash up; I'll get going . dn the kitchen... oo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frady stands at the mirror beside tin shower stall, a tow around his middle, giving himself a go-over with an elect razor. Propped on little shelf in front of him is one of those xerox sheets from Hildy's legacy. It's the same one he looked at in her room. As Frady studies it again, we c read the heading typed in caps. “ARTHUR FAVERSHAM. DROWNE WHILE FISHING. SALMONTAIL RIVER, IDAHO.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice and cozy. Frady and Pelikas sit at the table, with bowls of stew and mugs of coffee. Pelikas can talk with his mouth full or empty. se :

dialogues.speaker: PELIKAS
dialogues.text: Fishing's held up better, than the hunting. Nowadays, you let go a round in November, you're like to put a hole in a eight-thousand- dollar camper with four beds and a color TV. And if you did find a bear, he'd sit up and beg for peanut butter and jelly. But the fishing's okay. cont  ©)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad. I always heard so much about this river from my friend Art Faversham. Pelikas reacts, stares at Prady.

dialogues.speaker: PELIKAS
dialogues.text: Oh Jesus. That's what I meant about lucky seven, maybe. He was staying here. In the very same cabin you're in, didja know that?

dialogues.speaker: CU
dialogues.text: He looks suitably startled, lowers his fork. ANGLE LOOSEN Pelikas has reached for a canister labeled “Flour” and re moved top, taken out a bottle of brandy. Pours a dollop> -into FPrady's coffee mug.

dialogues.speaker: PELIKAS
dialogues.text: O£ course I'll move you now. FRADY . Thanks.. It's okay. I mean it was - a damn shame, but -- way I look at - it, least he went doing something he liked. Beats old age and cancer.

dialogues.speaker: . PELIXAS
dialogues.text: . Well, yeah. That is a way to look at it.

dialogues.speaker: , FRADY
dialogues.text: I always been Curious, though. - Art was no greenhorn on rivers.

dialogues.speaker: PELIXAS
dialogues.text: Hell. Old days, there'd be maybe one gone a season, this stretch. You mean you don't know the setup? (as Frady shakes head) . What happens is, there's this big reservoir up in the notch, say here, for the power company --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - Moving sugar bowl to demonstrate, arranging utensils as goes on: CONT.

dialogues.speaker: PELIKAS _ .
dialogues.text: Don't draw enough water out, it backs up, so they open the sluice there and that overflow comes down like a wall. You're standing let's say here, where the side stream runs through this here little gorge, there's about a four-foot drop anyway, and you're caught there -- you're gonna drown, green horns or blue.

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: Isn't there any warning system?

dialogues.speaker: PELIKAS -
dialogues.text: Oh sure. Big signs, and a siren and bells. And there's this : ~ watchman, kind of, who hangs along the xiver. That's Buster Meyer. Not that he's-worth much on the job anymore. Bought a new car, bought a four-hundred-dollar Browning shotgun. Son of 2 bitch come into money some way. PUSH IN on Frady. He freezes with coffee mug halfway to lips, narrows eyes fairly theatrically. * PRADY ° Don't tell me -- it happened just after my friend Art had his accident.

dialogues.speaker: PELIKAS
dialogues.text: Yep, it did. What you mean? ra FRADY Art didn't hear the warnings -- because someone screwed 'em up.

dialogues.speaker: PELIKAS
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: Art was rich. His wife's a sexpot twenty years younger. Then this so-called watchman comes into heavy bread. CONT.  27.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Pelikas stares at Frady, fascinated by this touch of melodrama. :

dialogues.speaker: \ PELIKAS
dialogues.text: You from the insurance company?

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: Nope. Just a friend. But I wouldn't mind a talk with Buster Meyer.

dialogues.speaker: PELIKAS
dialogues.text: . He's zat-ass mean, Mr. Harmon.

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: Jack, to you.

dialogues.speaker: PELIKAS
dialogues.text: Henry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you fix it for us to talk?

dialogues.speaker: . . PELIKAS
dialogues.text: Sure. .Easy. I. could take you to the bowling tomorrow night. (very worried) But I mean he is mean, Jack. He figures you for any ideas, you're taking some chance. Frady has finished eating. He stands up with a grin.

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: I took one on your stew and it paid off, Henry. Maybe I'm on a streak.

dialogues.speaker: PELIKAS
dialogues.text: Okay. I'll fix it.

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: Thanks, Henry. But listen -- you breathe a word I'm asking questions, you'll have an accident yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell. . I'm like a gravestone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a r~ ey

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OPEN CU on one of those WARNING SIGNS Pelikas mentioned. CAMERA PULLS to reveal the narrow gorge and four-foot Niagara described last night. Frady is on a big jutting slab at the side, above the little falls, casting down in turquoise pool below. He has just reeled in when Pelikas emerges from trees behind. He has a shotgun slung on his back and carries a paper~sack.

dialogues.speaker: . PELIKAS
dialogues.text: How's the luck?

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: all with the fish.

dialogues.speaker: PELIKAS
dialogues.text: Feel like eating, Jack, I brung you up some lunch.

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: Hey -- that's very nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coming in on the rock, catching the sack which Pelikas tosses to him. He pulls out a sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: PRADY
dialogues.text: You give everyone this service, Henry, you'll lose a -- Sudden BLAST OF SIREN from upstream. Frady spins. Its loudness is really startling in this narrow gorge. Then a GONG starts sounding, and they go together for a bit, and then both DIE AWAY as startlingly as they began. Prady takes a bite of his sandwich, staring. upstream toward source of sound, in some awe. CAMERA IN on him.

dialogues.speaker: PRADY
dialogues.text: My God. No one could miss that.

dialogues.speaker: PELIKAS
dialogues.text: You'd think not.

dialogues.speaker: PRADY
dialogues.text: Now I really want to talk with Meyer.

dialogues.speaker: PELIKAS
dialogues.text: There isn't any Meyer, you’know. Very quiet, that last. Offhand. But Frady gets it instant He's aware of his own mouth opening in mid-chew, the bite liverwurst and bread lying against his lower teeth as his - head turns.

dialogues.speaker: INCLUDING PELIKAS
dialogues.text: He has that shotgun unslung now. “It's a new Browning. ~ Frady chokes, spits out his mouthful onto the rock.

dialogues.speaker: PELIKAS
dialogues.text: Don't do anything, now. I don't want to shoot you now. :

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: I'm a police officer. Drop your weapon!

dialogues.speaker: PELIKAS
dialogues.text: Shit. You got about two minutes. Warning goes once more, then the third time you're in the drink like your pal Art. Big casino. FRADY a ~~ You penny-ante cracsy. :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Been called a lot worse for a lot - . less. . - . . FRADY . What'd you do it for, two hundred cash? | . PELIKAS . . FPifty-two-thousand five. Plus I - oughta get a bonus for you. Very simplicity of his tone says that Pelikas is telling truth. This is rather worse than Frady thought. He feels the blood draining from his face. .

dialogues.speaker: PRADY
dialogues.text: Who from? - ° PELIRAS Don't be a sap.

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: Who's paying you?

dialogues.speaker: , PELIKAS
dialogues.text: Aw come on. I told you. I'ma gravestone, Fury of SIREN AND GONG echoes briefly through gorge again dies away. CONT.  oy a 30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next one's wet, Jack. Prady shakes his head, changing his tack.

dialogues.speaker: FRAD
dialogues.text: It's a bad joke. You wouldn't believe me if I told you.

dialogues.speaker: PELIKAS
dialogues.text: What? -

dialogues.speaker: G . FRADY
dialogues.text: . . I liked you so much last night. Way you shared with me. I was trying to think:of something I . could do for you, Henry. ~

dialogues.speaker: PELIKAS
dialogues.text: Just shut up, that'll do for me. Till I get my bonus. .

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: Bonus. Shit! Tiil they put a slug in the back of your head!

dialogues.speaker: PELIKAS
dialogues.text: No sir, Jack. Parallax folk 'd never -- cU = FRADY woe, eat ete As Pelikas bites that off.

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: Who? Parallax? Who would never what?? .

dialogues.speaker: ON PELIXAS
dialogues.text: He's a gravestone. He glances at his watch quickly, then up the river. Takes a step forward, the shotgun leveled.

dialogues.speaker: ON FRADY
dialogues.text: The passing seconds are drowning him.' With an easy littl movement, he reaches to touch the fly reeled up against tip ferrule of his rod. . :

dialogues.speaker: PELIKAS
dialogues.text: Don't do that!: I want that fly tied on there! CONT.

dialogues.speaker: PRADY
dialogues.text: I'm meant to been fishing, Henry, there should be more line out. Goofs like that take a fella to the gas chamber.

dialogues.speaker: SHOTS
dialogues.text: Pelikas hesitates an instant, then nods.

dialogues.speaker: PELIKAS
dialogues.text: Okay. Little more line out. Frady drawing out line, lazily, and then suddenly it's li with the rookie Troopers as he backhand-slashes rod over Pelikas's eyes and dives at his ankles. Big BOOM! of shot as Pelikas goes down, and now SIREN AND GONG start again, second barrel goes BOOM! and from upstream a SOUND LIKE S They grapple grunting, Frady's fingers still dug into ank and then Frady is up on knees, yanking up as if at a leve

dialogues.speaker: PELIKAS AND THE RIVER ,
dialogues.text: The man is poised a beat, limned against frothy wali of w rushing down, crest boiling with small rocks and brush. T with a SCREAM, still clutching gun, he flips into the wav Head bobs up, gets smashed hideously into rocks. One foot in air, tumbling, and Pelikas has vanished.

dialogues.speaker: ON FRADY
dialogues.text: Watching the wild riverrun, its crest gone down the gorge Frady rises from hands and knees. He kicks the bag and remains of sandwich into the drink, picks up rod and cree and walks away from the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prady's over the desk in front hall. He pulls out all the drawers and gives them a quick search... He finds nothing special interest. He turns and goes upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frady stands a moment, getting the room's vibes. He's a pro at this. He goes to bureau, pulls out the right top drawer, pushes aside socks and stuff. There's a cheap revolver under them. This Saturday Night Special neither surprises nor interests Frady. He leaves it as it was, crosses and throws mattress off the bed. Nothing under it The vibes draw him to a closet. He reaches up onto top sh Behind a fur hat there's a FISHING BOX, like you keep fli CONT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on 32.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: and things in. He takes it down. The box is locked. Frady seems pleased that it is locked. He leaves the bedroom wi t.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frady gets the box open with a wrecking bar from rack on wall. Top layer has little compartments filled with flies and sinkers, etc. He swings that up on its metal arms. Underneath is a helluva lot of U.S. currency. Frady shuts box again, takes it into house through the connecting doo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three stacks of bills on table: $20s, $50s and $100s. Pra has jotted amounts in each denomination on a pad. MOVE IN OVER SHOULDER as he does bit more arithmetic:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat, and then the pencil adds "2777." “BACK TO FRADY He frowns. Assuming Pelikas told truth about what he was paid, and there's no reason to doubt it, almost half the sum is not accounted for. Frady returns to beat-up fishin box. Bottom part is empty all right: no savings account passbook or bonds or anything. He's leaving the box again when something catches at his eye. He reaches under a mes of lead sinkers in top part, comes up with a folded bit o NEWSPRINT. He unfolds it and stares at it and his eyes narrow.

dialogues.speaker: CU
dialogues.text: It's a medium-size box advertisement clipped from some ne paper. We've all seen ones just like it. Big bold head Says: "HIGH-PAID JOBS OVERSEAS!" ‘Then there's bit of pri and another bold line: “YOU MIGHT QUALIFY!" A bit more pr and then the bottom line that jumps out at you too: "APPL

dialogues.speaker: IN PERSON DEC. 18
dialogues.text: ciITy.*

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reading it and rereading ‘it, fascinated, as there is a S 0.8. A CAR coming in and stopping. So great is Prady's interest in this ad that he doesn't react until there's another SOUND: the definite SLAM OF A CAR DOOR. He whirls around and goes to front kitchen window.  iy ry

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WOMAN and a BOY have gotten out of their car. The Boy i around 12. She's maybe 34, as attractive as anyone would want, in a great tough-slender way that suggests she used to be a model. The kid totes small suitcase and a canvas fishing-rod holder, and both of them appear just a bit travel-worn. CAMERA TRACKS in front of them as they walk up into the h and stop short just over the threshold.

dialogues.speaker: THE WOMAN
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: Sorry, folk. Closed down for remodeling. ~ They stare at him. Frady picks up an Auto Club Motel Guid from desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whyn't I call and get you in someplace? ‘THE WOMAN ° (calling loud) Henry -- 7?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Prady) What you done with him? -

dialogues.speaker: CU
dialogues.text: He's as silent as the house. He looks like an idiot. ANGL LOOSENS as the Woman turns back to him. Her eyes are very wary and deep.

dialogues.speaker: THE WOMAN
dialogues.text: I'm Marian Gay. This is my son Todd. We're staying here. Who in hell are you?

dialogues.speaker: PRADY
dialogues.text: I just got here, ma'am. Door was open and I didn't see anyone so -~ . ” . . Frady trails off. Marian has coolly plucked his card from slot, is looking at it. CONT.

dialogues.speaker: MARIAN
dialogues.text: John Harmon. Cabin 7. Odd you checked in last night, then.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: Shouldn't we call Sheriff Mapes?

dialogues.speaker: MARIAN
dialogues.text: Probably yes. (gaze back on Frady) Where's Henry Pelikas?

dialogues.speaker: PRADY
dialogues.text: . Who? -- Oh. I dunno. He said he was going fishing.

dialogues.speaker: MARIAN
dialogues.text: Go look for him, Todd. Along the ~ river?

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: We oughta call the sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: MARIAN
dialogues.text: Just look for Mr. Pelikas. And be careful. Todd gives Frady a hugely hostile look, but he goes down hall toward back of house.

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: Truth is, I'ma -- little crazy. © .

dialogues.speaker: MARIAN
dialogues.text: (solemn deadpan) But not dangerously.

dialogues.speaker: FRADY
dialogues.text: No, ma'am, Just from working too hard. Doc said I'd be fine if I took a rest. I don't know what got into me. Todd suddenly turns in the b.g. TODD ‘ _ Hank went fishing, huh?

dialogues.speaker: . PRADY
dialogues.text: That's what he said. CONT.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: TODD ” Funny. Because his rod's here but his shotgun isn't. cU - MARIAN , Stops breathing for an instant. Just an instant.

dialogues.speaker: MARIAN
dialogues.text: Look for him, dear. Along the river and be very careful. cu - TODD He's going to say something more, but changes mind. Glare at Frady again and exits by door at end of hall. . :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope nothing's wrong. Seemed such a nice fella. Cooked me up a great breakfast. She doesn't make any comment. She studies him with a sort of calculation, then turns. CAMERA TRACKS WITH HER as she walks through the dining room and into the kitchen. Her eyes start sweeping, then they freeze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ZOOM IN on that fishing box. It lies on its side on the table, open and bashed and empty. Flies and lead sinkers are scattered around, but Frady must have had time to stu the money out of sight somewhere. .

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO MARIAN
dialogues.text: She goes and looks.into the garbage pail. She returns to the table. The note-pad lies there, with Frady's arithmet still on the top sheet. She picks it up and looks at it, drops it again and turns.

dialogues.speaker: INCLUDE FRADY
dialogues.text: He has strolled into kitchen after her sometime, stands w his head dumbly cocked. .

dialogues.speaker: . MARIAN
dialogues.text: You've been working too hard. CONT.  36.

dialogues.speaker: FRADY

dialogues.speaker: VOICE OVER
dialogues.text: You are about to be TESTED for JOB SUITABILITY. The test begins the moment you enter the PARALLAX SUITE. If YOUR test is to have value, VALUE, if it is to measure YOUR capabilities, you must follow INSTRUCTIONS as exactly, EXACTLY, as possible. SAY NOTHING or DO NOTHING that you are not DIRECTED : ~ to SAY or DO. Here is an EXAMPLE. You now hold a CARD. It bears YOUR NAME and-a SIX DIGIT NUMERAL. When and IF you are selected to proceed from the INTRODUCTORY Parallax Suite to an INDIVIDUAL TEST AREA, you must respond to that DIRECTION with the first INITIAL of your LAST name plus the FIRST FIVE digits of the numeral which follows. If the . numeral after YOUR name were printed as, for EXAMPLE, 1-3 space 8-7-6 space 4, you would respond with your INITIAL plus 1-3-8-7-6. - Note that in this context the printed SPACES would NOT be AUDIBLY VOCALIZED. Vocalization of the SPACES would be an ERROR. Errors cost POINTS. Errors will cause MANY of you to FAIL. Those who FAIL cannot be considered for a HIGH-PAID JOB OVERSEAS. To repeat, REPEAT, you must SAY NOTHING or DO NOTHING that you are not DIRECTED to SAY OR DO. fhe Parallax Corporation is a nationally recognized testing institute which conducts tests for MANY gf America's LEADING MANUFACTURERS and ORGANIZATIONS.
